revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Will Smith | image = http://www.comedycv.co.uk/willsmith/will-smith-2011-march.jpg | birth_name = William James Smith | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|6|8|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nb2007010621.html |title=Smith, Will, 1971- - LC Linked Data Service | Library of Congress |publisher=Id.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2017-03-30}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Winchester]], [[Hampshire]], [[England]] | nationality = British | years_active = 1996–present | known_for = TV, film and radio comedy | occupation = Actor, screenwriter, stand-up comedian, novelist, producer }} '''William James Smith''' (born 8 June 1971) is an English stand-up comedian, screenwriter, novelist, actor and producer.
As co-writer and co-producer of the [[HBO]] sitcom ''[[Veep (TV series)|Veep]]'', he was among the recipients of two [[Emmy Award|Emmy]]s and two [[Writers Guild of America Award]]s, and has received nominations for the [[Golden Globe Award]] and the [[Producers Guild of America Award for Best Episodic Comedy]].<ref name="emmys">{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2015/outstanding-comedy-series|publisher=emmys.com|title=Nominees/Winners | Television Academy|accessdate=9 September 2016}} {{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2016/outstanding-comedy-series|publisher=emmys.com|title=Nominees/Winners | Television Academy|accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="goldenglobes">{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenglobes.com/tv-show/veep|publisher=goldenglobes.com|title=Veep | Golden Globes|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="wga">{{cite web|url=http://awards.wga.org/wga-awards/nominees-winners|publisher=awards.wga.org|title=2016 Writers Guild Awards Nominees|accessdate=9 September 2016|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018003632/http://awards.wga.org/wga-awards/nominees-winners|archivedate=18 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="hollywoodreporter">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/2016-pga-nominations-complete-list-856980/item/outstanding-producer-episodic-television-comedy-856974|publisher=hollywoodreporter.com|title=2016 PGA Nominations (Complete List) | Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=9 September 2016}} {{cite web|url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/2017-pga-award-nominations-960097/item/danny-thomas-award-outstanding-producer-episodic-television-comedy-2017-pga-nominations-960092 |publisher=hollywoodreporter.com|title=2017 PGA Nominations (Complete List) | Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=12 November 2017}} </ref>
==Early life and education== Though born in [[Winchester]], [[Hampshire]],<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/features/will-smiths-new-book-mainlander-john-le-carr-meets-middlemarch-10037021.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211051847/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/features/will-smiths-new-book-mainlander-john-le-carr-meets-middlemarch-10037021.html |date=11 February 2015 }}</ref> Smith grew up in Jersey and was educated there at [[Victoria College, Jersey|Victoria College]]. His brother is the TV presenter and wine critic [[Olly Smith]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/jollyolly/status/63616733273014272 |title=Twitter / jollyolly: @tvpeanuts Yes I am related |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref>
==Stand up comedy== Smith started his career in [[stand-up comedy]], winning awards including [[Chortle Awards|Chortle Best Headliner 2005]] and [[Time Out Comedy Awards|Time Out Comedy 2004]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/w/76/will_smith |title=Will Smith on : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide |publisher=Chortle |date= |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> One critic called him 'the [[Hugh Grant]] of comedy',<ref name="independent1">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/features/will-smiths-new-book-mainlander-john-le-carr-meets-middlemarch-10037021.html |title=Will Smith's New Book: John Le Carre Meets Middlemarch |publisher=Independent |date= |accessdate=10 March 2015}}</ref> and he appeared in ''[[The 11 O'Clock Show]]'' with [[Sacha Baron Cohen]] and [[Ricky Gervais]] as the character 'Posh Boy'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0224452/fullcredits/|title=The 11 O'Clock Show (1998–2000) : Full Cast & Crew|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> He took solo shows to the [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]] every year from 2003 to 2006: "Will Smith Is Much Obliged", "Misplaced Childhood" (inspired by his love of the rock band [[Marillion]] and [[Misplaced Childhood|their 1985 album of the same name]]),<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.getreadytorock.com/bstage_heroes/will_smith.htm | title= Interview: Will Smith | publisher=Get Ready to Rock | first=Jason | last=Ritchie | accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> "Ten Arguments I Should Have Won",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2004/w/1295/will_smith%3A_10_arguments_i_should_have_won/review?id_review=1295 |title=Will Smith: 10 Arguments I Should Have Won' review : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide |publisher=Chortle |date= |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> and "How To Be Cool".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2006/w/14893/will_smith%3A_how_to_be_cool/review?id_review=14893 |title=Will Smith: How To Be Cool' review : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide |publisher=Chortle |date= |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> Smith supported Gervais on his record-breaking sell-out [[Fame (2007 film)|2007 "Fame" tour]], and supported [[Ardal O'Hanlon]] and [[Johnny Vegas]] on national tours.
==Television== With [[Armando Iannucci]] and [[Roger Drew]] he devised BBC future comedy ''[[Time Trumpet]]'', six episodes that screened in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timetrumpet.co.uk/credits.htm |title=Credits |publisher=Time Trumpet |date= |accessdate=25 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303183253/http://www.timetrumpet.co.uk/credits.htm |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Smith is involved with both British and American [[political satire]]. He is a writer and one of the [[Television producer#Types of television producers|executive producers]] on [[HBO]]'s [[Emmy Award|Emmy]]-winning [[sitcom]] ''[[Veep (TV series)|Veep]]'', starring [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]].<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite web|author=Will Smith |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/feb/21/will-smith-screenwriter-turns-novelist |title=A screenwriter turns novelist, looking for less interference and fewer turkeys | Books |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> He wrote or co-wrote the Veep episodes: Chung (Season 1); Midterms, Running (Season 2); Some New Beginnings, Fishing (Season 3); Storms and Pancakes, Testimony (Season 4); Thanksgiving, C**tgate (Season 5){{citation needed|date=May 2016}}. Smith also wrote on the [[BAFTA]]-winning BBC political comedy ''[[The Thick of It]]''. He was the only writer on the programme who acted in it – as MP Peter Mannion's inept adviser, ''[[Lord of the Rings]]''-obsessive Phil Smith. He also has a [[cameo role]] in the closing credits of ''[[In the Loop]]'', the Anglo-American film spin-off.
He is also a writer on the sitcom ''[[Damned (TV series)]]'' and contributed additional material to ''Back'', both airing on Channel 4.{{cn|date=November 2017}}
==Books== Comedy books by Smith include ''How To Be Cool''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/How-Be-Cool-Social-Blunders/dp/0719524903 |title=How to Be Cool: Make Social Blunders a Thing of the Past!: Amazon.co.uk: Will Smith: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> ([[Harry Enfield]] said of it 'Will Smith is the coolest guy in the world (if uncool is the new cool) – he's also terrifically funny'), and ''The Joy of No Sex'', published by [[Penguin Group|Penguin]],<ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0718148371 |title=The Joy of No Sex: A Guide to Life Without Lovemaking: Amazon.co.uk: Will Smith, Roger Drew |isbn=9780718148379 |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> a parody of ''[[The Joy of Sex]]''.
Smith writes for various publications, including the magazine ''[[Intelligent Life (magazine)|Intelligent Life]]'', in which he learns something new for each issue. Articles have included banjo-playing, ice-sculpting, circus skills and making a [[soufflé]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moreintelligentlife.com/content/will-smith-learns-do-something-new-this-issue-the-banjo |accessdate=8 October 2008 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In 2015 Smith published his first novel, ''Mainlander'' (4th Estate, a division of [[HarperCollins]]),<ref>{{cite book|author=Will Smith |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Mainlander-Will-Smith/dp/0007594267 |title=Mainlander |isbn=9780007594269 |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> a thriller about a schoolboy who goes missing on Jersey. ''[[The Independent]]'' described it as '[[John le Carré]] meets [[Middlemarch]]',<ref name="independent1"/> and [[ShortList]] called it a 'knockout'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shortlist.com/entertainment/books/the-shortread-will-smith |title=The ShortRead: Will Smith | ShortList Magazine |publisher=Shortlist.com |date= |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' also gave it a positive review, hailing it as 'a proper work of fiction... A carefully worked plot, seen through the viewpoints of a clutch of cast members, builds nicely to a satisfying climax.'<ref>{{cite web|last=Ritchie |first=Harry |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/books/article-2960581/LITERARY-FICTION.html#ixzz3U4lpKk9b |title=LITERARY FICTION | Daily Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=19 February 2015 |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>
Smith reflects on the difference between writing for television and writing a novel in ''[[The Guardian]]''. "The chain from author to reader is short and simple – agent, editor, proofreader, shop/website. In TV, the script will have to be signed off by producers, executive producers, genre commissioners and channel commissioners, and that’s still only a starting point". He cites as his influences [[John Cleese]] and [[Stephen Fry]], as well as [[Charlotte Bronte]] and [[George Eliot]].<ref name="theguardian1"/>
==Radio== Smith appears on [[BBC Radio 4]], both as a guest in comedy [[panel show]]s, as well as in his own shows. * ''[[Armando Iannucci's Charm Offensive]]'' * ''[[Banter (radio show)|Banter]]'' (2002, 2007) * ''[[The Personality Test]]'' (2003–09)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/people/VGVmL25hbWUvc21pdGgsIHdpbGwgKGNvbWVkaWFuKQ|title=BBC – Programmes – Categorised as will smith|accessdate=18 April 2009}}</ref> * ''[[Will Smith Presents the Tao of Bergerac]]'' (2007), based on [[Bergerac (TV series)|the 1980s TV series set on Jersey]]. Released as a BBC Audio CD in 2008.<ref>{{cite book|author=Will Smith |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1405677422 |title=Will Smith Presents: The Tao of Bergerac (BBC Audio) |isbn=9781405677424 |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> * ''Will Smith's Midlife Crisis Management'' (2005) * ''[[It's Your Round]]'' (2011) * ''[[Mr. & Mrs. Smith (radio)|Mr and Mrs Smith]]'' (2012) Sitcom about a couple in marriage counselling.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01bgnxm |title=BBC Radio 4 – Mr and Mrs Smith |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=21 February 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref>
==Credits== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1997 | ''[[The 11 O'Clock Show]]'' | | |- | 2000 | ''[[Time Gentlemen Please]]'' | | |- | 2003 | ''[[Gash (TV series)|Gash]]'' | | |- | 2004 | ''[[A Wife For William]]'' | | |- | 2005 | ''[[The Comic Side of 7 Days]]'' | | |- | 2005 | ''Back in the Day'' | | |- | 2006 | ''[[The Charlotte Church Show]]'' | | |- | 2006 | ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' | | |- | 2006–2012 | ''[[The Thick of It]]'' | [[List of The Thick of It characters#Her Majesty's Most Loyal Opposition|Phil Smith]] | 2006, one-hour special in 2007, 2009, 2012 |- | 2007 | ''The C Word'' |The euphemism for "[[Cunt#Television|cunt]]", not "cancer" | |- | 2007 | ''[[The Late Edition]]'' | | |- | 2008 | ''For One Night Only'' | | |- | 2009 | ''[[Argumental]]'' | | 2 guest appearances |- | 2011 | ''[[Comedy Lab]]'' | Tony | Season 12, Episode 5 |- | 2012 | ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' | | |- | 2012 | ''[[Dead Boss]]'' | Governor Gorey | Season 1, Episode 6 |}
